Award.AwardTitle: CC* Networking Infrastructure: Science DMZ and Research Network Upgrade for Louisiana State University Health Sciences Center New Orleans

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This CC* Networking Infrastructure project at LSU Health Sciences Center New Orleans (LSUHSC-NO) is constructing a high-speed science network to connect LSUHSC-NO's research areas to facilitate unimpeded movement of large data sets and to provide a pathway to national and global high-performance computing resources. The project enables researchers, scientists, and students to exchange and store large data sets, to expand their opportunities for remote collaboration, and to facilitate leadership in research and education within multiple disciplines of Science at LSUHSC-NO: Anatomy, Biochemistry, Cell Biology, Genetics, Hematology, Immunology, Microbiology, Molecular Biology, Oncology, Ophthalmology, Parasitology, Pathology, Pharmacology, and Physiology. This project has broader implications for the scientific community including the next generation of researchers and scientists. Whether it is a high school student pondering one's future by participating in a summer research program or internship, a budding student enrolled in curricula at LSUHSC-NO, or a collaborative researcher somewhere in cyberspace, this project is key to the future of research at LSUHSC-NO and this project unlocks the door to many exciting discoveries.

This project consists of three objectives: (i) Upgrade the distribution and access layer networking infrastructure to provide 10Gbps and/or 1Gbps ports in the research areas; (ii) Re-architect the campus network to support large data flows by designing and building a Science DMZ; and (iii) Connect to LSUHSC-NO's regional optical exchange's Science DMZ via 20Gbps connections.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project upgraded the distribution and access layer networking infrastructure to provide 10Gbps and/or 1Gbps ports in the research areas at Louisiana State University Health Sciences Center - New Orleans (LSUHSC-NO), redesigned LSUHSC-NO's campus network to support large data flows by designing and building a Science DMZ, and connected LSUHSC-NO's network to its regional optical exchange's (LONI) Science DMZ via 20Gbps connections. 

This project has provided researchers ability to improve existing collaborations and to advance future collaborations. Researchers have direct high-speed access to in-state collaborators via LONI. LSUHSC-NO's researchers now have faster access to Internet2 and other research networks to facilitate collaborations outside of the state of Louisiana. Due to the increased data transfer rates, they have immediate access to data and the results they need to continue their research. LSUHSC-NO researchers are utilizing to the NSF-funded supercomputing resources at LSU and other institutions. This project has formed a relationship between IT and the scientific community and LSUHSC-NO's IT department is in a better position to assist the research community. 

The creation of a high-speed science network is a complex and extensive project.   LSUHSC-NO has shared the implementation experiences and lessons learned during this project with other universities to ensure their efforts to create a high-speed science network also succeed.
